results.title: Remembering Life
results.brief_description: A history of Life magazine which first appeared in America in November 1936. Life pioneered pictorial journalism and in the process radically altered the course of the print media. Editors, journalists and photographers involved with its production, discuss the incredible power and influence had by this pictorial.

results.title: Remembering Jacqueline du Pre
results.brief_description: The life of cellist Jacqueline du Pre was tragically cut short when she died of multiple sclerosis, aged 28. This film contains footage of du Pre in her element, practicing amongst friends and performing to receptive and adoring audiences. The second half of the program features performances. Extracts include Brahms: Sonata No.2 in F, Op.99; Offenbach: Duos for two cellos; Beethoven: Sonata No.3 in A, Op.69; Schubert: Piano Quintet in A, D.667 “The Trout”; Beethoven: Piano Trio No.5 in D, Op.70 No.1 “The Ghost”; Elgar: and Cello Concerto in E minor, Op.85.

results.title: Remembering country (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Charlotte Seymour, Harold Furber and Kate Gillick
results.brief_description: An autobiographical documentary which tells the story of a member of the ‘stolen generation’ of Aboriginal children of mixed descent. In 1957 at age four, Harold Furber was taken from the desert regions near Alice Springs by the Commonwealth Government, and placed in a Methodist missionary camp on Croker Island, 225 km north-east of Darwin. Telling his story through the use of slides and archival footage taken at the mission during the fifties and sixties, Furber recounts a childhood where his fragile but growing feeling of belonging to a new family and home on Croker Island, was continually shattered by the confusion and sense of loss and pain caused by his separation from his family and his country. Carrying a deep sense of alienation and bitterness into his adult life, Furber attempts through this documentary, to reconstruct his fractured identity by reconnecting with his birthplace and community. Narrated by Harold Furber. Written by Kate Gillick and Harold Furber.

results.title: Remedial reading; Helping you to help your child
results.creator_credit: Audiovisual Centre, University of Auckland and Bill Cole
results.brief_description: Remedial reading: a family affair [22:00] deals with a research project in the Mangere district of South Auckland which aimed to clarify parental willingness to assist their children with reading difficulties, how they could be helped and whether this assistance was of lasting benefit. “Helping you to help your child” [23:00] introduces parents to the essential components in tutoring children: praising, problem solving, pausing and beginnings. The program is directed towards parents of older children who have reading difficulties.
results.title_for_label: Remedial reading; Helping you to help your child

results.title: Rembrandt: painter of man
results.creator_credit: Bert Haanstra Film Productions, Coronet Instructional Films and Bert Haanstra
results.brief_description: Presents selected canvases gathered from twenty-nine museums in twelve countries. These paintings highlight Rembrandt’s use of light and shadow, and his ability to express compassion for his subjects.

results.title: Rembrandt: draughtsman
results.creator_credit: Nederlandse Omroep Stichting, Rijksmuseum Amsterdam, Hans Nieman, Tina De Vrij and Kees van Langeraad
results.brief_description: The paintings of Dutch 17th century painter Rembrandt van Rijn, are world famous, but a large number of his beautiful drawings have never been seen by the public. This film explores this rich oeuvre, setting it in the context of Rembrandt’s life, his work, his contemporaries and the society of 17th century Holland.

results.title: Rembrandt's - The Three Crosses
results.creator_credit: Balfour Films, Arts Council of Great Britain and Dudley Shaw Ashton
results.brief_description: A detailed account of the engraving of the original plate for Rembrandt’s celebrated print; the artist’s experimental use of different papers and methods of inking, and the later re-working of the plate. Commentary written and spoken by Christopher White.
